ENTRY.SYNOPSIS: Return the data used to create the radial or elliptical profile of the residuals (data - model) to imaging data.

SYNTAX.LINE: get_resid_prof( [id], [model=None, rstep=None, rmin=None, rmax=None, rlo=None, rhi=None, xpos=None, ypos=None, ellip=None, theta=None, group_counts=None, group_snr=None, recalc=True] )

DESC.PARA: The get_resid_prof() command calculates the radial - or elliptical - profile of the residuals to imaging data and returns an object containing the values. The profile is defined by the existing model compenents, although it is possible to over-ride these values.
The residual values are calculated as data - model The get_delchi_prof() command can be used if you want to use (data - model) / error
The routine can be loaded into Sherpa by saying:
The argument options are the same as for the prof_resid() command - except that the overplot and label arguments are not supported - and are described in its ahelp page.

ROW.DATA: The lower-limits of the radial bins
The upper-limits of the radial bins
The calculated profile value; sum of (data - model) / area
The label for the X axis
The label for the Y axis
The labels giving the profile parameters

DESC.PARA: Two profiles of the same dataset are calculated; d10 uses a signal-to-noise ratio of 10 and d20 a value of 20.

A profile is calculated and displayed for the dataset "src1". The bin edges from this are then used to create a profile for the dataset "src2", which is overlain on the first plot. Note that recalc is set to False in the call to get_resid_prof() to avoid unnescessary re-calculations.
